191 personnes ont trouvÃ© cette Ã©valuation utile
2 personnes ont trouvÃ© cette Ã©valuation amusante
10
Non recommandÃ©
4.1 h en tout
Ã‰valuation publiÃ©e le 4 mars 2021
OK, let me start off by saying that I was really looking forward to this game, and I wanted it to be good, I really did. The premise is wonderful: a 3D puzzle game based on recursive geometry and scale manipulation. The trailer made it look like a game that I would be in love with. Annapurna Interactive has an unbelievably good track record in choosing the games that they publish, so when I see their logo next to a title, it is almost like a seal of quality for me.

But Maquette... is not a good puzzle game, unfortunately. Nor is it a good story game. The camera and the controls are slightly jittery, which gave me a constant feeling of not quite being in full control most of the time, and that is pretty unpleasant. The puzzle design had a lot of potential, as this is a pretty brilliant foundation for a puzzle game, but it falls way short in terms of setting its expectations, and communicating the language of its world to the player. It jumps from idea to idea with very little in the way of connective tissue. Instead of building upon the puzzle language to create more and more intricate puzzles to solve that relate to the player's intuition in a fun way, it just discards ideas as soon as each puzzle is solved, and starts from scratch each time.
Because of this, I rarely felt like I knew if I was doing what the game expected me to do, or if I was finding cheese left and right, breaking the fragile physics of this recursive world. In this way, solving the puzzles wasn't very satisfying, because I never really knew if I was actually solving them or not.
I went into the game expecting a puzzle wonderland, akin to Superliminal, Manifold Garden, Portal, or The Witness and maybe that expectation ruined me, because it simply did not match up to my hopes as a puzzle game.
I will say, however, that the final level is transcendent, and I kind of wish that the whole game was based on that final level, instead of whatever else was going on here.

There is an ongoing story being narrated as you make your way through the puzzles, and in my opinion, the voice actors (who I later learned are husband and wife, which is adorable) are quite excellent, and they kept me engaged, despite the story being perhaps the most generic, bland relationship story I have ever experienced. The story was connected to the puzzles by only the loosest of threads, so it didn't even need to be in the game, as far as I'm concerned.

I'm sorry that this is such a negative review. I really had high hopes for Maquette, and I feel kind of deflated now that I've played it.
My recommendation, if you are interested in Maquette, but haven't yet played Superliminal or Manifold Garden, is to play those first. I promise you will enjoy both of those in the way that you are hoping to enjoy Maquette. If you've played those games already and are looking for more perspective-bending puzzle games, I'd say give Maquette a try, but temper your expectations, please.
 
aimawish
2

4.4 h en tout

Ğ¡ ÑĞ°Ğ¼Ğ¾Ğ³Ğ¾ Ğ½Ğ°Ñ‡Ğ°Ğ»Ğ° ÑÑ‚Ğ°Ğ½Ğ¾Ğ²Ğ¸Ñ‚ÑÑ Ğ¿Ğ¾Ğ½ÑÑ‚Ğ½Ğ¾, Ñ‡Ñ‚Ğ¾ Ğ½Ğ¸ĞºĞ°ĞºĞ¾Ğ¹ ÑĞ²ÑĞ·Ğ¸ Ğ¼ĞµĞ¶Ğ´Ñƒ ÑÑĞ¶ĞµÑ‚Ğ¾Ğ¼ Ğ¸ Ğ¸Ğ³Ñ€Ğ¾Ğ²Ñ‹Ğ¼ Ğ¿Ñ€Ğ¾Ñ†ĞµÑÑĞ¾Ğ¼ Ğ½ĞµÑ‚, Ğ¸ Ñ‡ĞµĞ¼ Ğ´Ğ°Ğ»ÑŒÑˆĞµ Ğ·Ğ°Ñ…Ğ¾Ğ´Ğ¸Ñ‚ Ğ¸Ğ³Ñ€Ğ¾Ğº, Ñ‚ĞµĞ¼ Ğ±Ğ¾Ğ»ĞµĞµ ÑÑ‚Ñ€Ğ°Ğ½Ğ½Ñ‹Ğµ, Ğ½ĞµĞ»ĞµĞ¿Ñ‹Ğµ Ğ¸ Ğ²Ğ·ÑÑ‚Ñ‹Ğµ Ñ Ğ¿Ğ¾Ñ‚Ğ¾Ğ»ĞºĞ° Ğ²ÑĞ¿Ğ»Ñ‹Ğ²Ğ°ÑÑ‚ Ğ³Ğ¾Ğ»Ğ¾Ğ²Ğ¾Ğ»Ğ¾Ğ¼ĞºĞ¸ (Ñ„Ğ¸Ğ½Ğ°Ğ»ÑŒĞ½Ğ°Ñ Ñ‡Ğ°ÑÑ‚ÑŒ Ğ² ÑÑ‚Ğ¾Ğ¼ Ğ¿Ğ»Ğ°Ğ½Ğµ Ğ¿Ğ¾Ğ»ÑƒÑ‡Ğ¸Ğ»Ğ°ÑÑŒ Ğ¾ÑĞ¾Ğ±ĞµĞ½Ğ½Ğ¾ Ğ²Ñ‹Ğ¼ÑƒÑ‡ĞµĞ½Ğ½Ğ¾Ğ¹, Ñ Ğ¿Ñ€Ğ¾Ğ´Ğ¸Ñ€Ğ°Ğ»ÑÑ Ñ‡ĞµÑ€ĞµĞ· Ğ½ĞµÑ‘ ÑÑƒĞ³ÑƒĞ±Ğ¾ Ñ Ğ¿Ñ€Ğ¾Ñ…Ğ¾Ğ¶Ğ´ĞµĞ½Ğ¸ĞµĞ¼). Ğ˜ Ğ»Ğ°Ğ´Ğ½Ğ¾ Ğ±Ñ‹ Ğ¾Ğ½Ğ¸ Ñ€Ğ°Ğ´Ğ¾Ğ²Ğ°Ğ»Ğ¸ Ñ€Ğ°Ğ·Ğ½Ğ¾Ğ¾Ğ±Ñ€Ğ°Ğ·Ğ¸ĞµĞ¼. Ğ’Ğ¾-Ğ¿ĞµÑ€Ğ²Ñ‹Ñ…, Ğ°Ğ²Ñ‚Ğ¾Ñ€Ñ‹ Ğ½Ğµ ÑÑ‡Ğ¸Ñ‚Ğ°ÑÑ‚ Ğ½ÑƒĞ¶Ğ½Ñ‹Ğ¼ Ğ½Ğ¾Ñ€Ğ¼Ğ°Ğ»ÑŒĞ½Ğ¾ Ğ¾Ğ±ÑŠÑÑĞ½ÑÑ‚ÑŒ Ğ½Ğ¾Ğ²Ñ‹Ğµ Ğ¼ĞµÑ…Ğ°Ğ½Ğ¸ĞºĞ¸, ĞºĞ¾Ñ‚Ğ¾Ñ€Ñ‹Ğµ Ğ½Ğµ ĞºĞ¾Ğ¼Ğ±Ğ¸Ğ½Ğ¸Ñ€ÑƒÑÑ‚ÑÑ, Ğ° Ğ¿Ñ€Ğ¾ÑÑ‚Ğ¾ Ñ‡ĞµÑ€ĞµĞ´ÑƒÑÑ‚ÑÑ Ğ² ÑĞ»ÑƒÑ‡Ğ°Ğ¹Ğ½Ğ¾Ğ¼ Ğ¿Ğ¾Ñ€ÑĞ´ĞºĞµ. Ğ’Ğ¾-Ğ²Ñ‚Ğ¾Ñ€Ñ‹Ñ…, Ğ½Ğ¸ĞºĞ°ĞºĞ¸Ñ… Ğ¾Ğ±Ñ‰Ğ¸Ñ… Ğ¿Ñ€Ğ°Ğ²Ğ¸Ğ» Ğ² Ğ¸Ğ³Ñ€Ğµ Ğ½ĞµÑ‚; Ğ²ÑÑ‘, Ğ½Ğ°Ñ‡Ğ¸Ğ½Ğ°Ñ Ğ¾Ñ‚ Ğ½ĞµĞ²Ğ¸Ğ´Ğ¸Ğ¼Ñ‹Ñ… ÑÑ‚ĞµĞ½ Ğ¸ Ğ·Ğ°ĞºĞ°Ğ½Ñ‡Ğ¸Ğ²Ğ°Ñ Ğ²Ğ¾Ğ·Ğ¼Ğ¾Ğ¶Ğ½Ğ¾ÑÑ‚ÑŒÑ Ğ¿Ğ¾Ğ´Ğ±Ğ¸Ñ€Ğ°Ñ‚ÑŒ Ñ‚Ğµ Ğ¸Ğ»Ğ¸ Ğ¸Ğ½Ñ‹Ğµ Ğ¿Ñ€ĞµĞ´Ğ¼ĞµÑ‚Ñ‹, Ğ¿Ğ¾ÑÑ‚Ğ¾ÑĞ½Ğ½Ğ¾ Ğ¼ĞµĞ½ÑĞµÑ‚ÑÑ Ğ¿Ğ¾Ğ´ ÑĞ¾Ğ²ĞµÑ€ÑˆĞµĞ½Ğ½Ğ¾ Ğ½ĞµĞ»Ğ¾Ğ³Ğ¸Ñ‡Ğ½Ñ‹Ğµ Ñ€ĞµÑˆĞµĞ½Ğ¸Ñ. ĞÑƒ Ğ¸ Ğ²-Ñ‚Ñ€ĞµÑ‚ÑŒĞ¸Ñ…, ÑƒĞ¿Ñ€Ğ°Ğ²Ğ»ĞµĞ½Ğ¸Ğµ Ñ‚ÑƒÑ‚ Ğ¿Ñ€Ğ¾ÑÑ‚Ğ¾ ÑƒĞ¶Ğ°ÑĞ½Ğ¾Ğµ. ĞŸĞ¾Ğ´Ğ½ÑÑ‚ÑŒ Ğ¸ Ğ¿Ğ¾Ğ»Ğ¾Ğ¶Ğ¸Ñ‚ÑŒ Ğ¿Ñ€ĞµĞ´Ğ¼ĞµÑ‚ â€“ ÑÑ‚Ğ¾ Ğ½Ğµ Ğ´Ğ²Ğµ ĞºĞ½Ğ¾Ğ¿ĞºĞ¸, Ğ° Ñ‡ĞµÑ‚Ñ‹Ñ€Ğµ. Ğ¯ ÑƒĞ¶ Ğ¼Ğ¾Ğ»Ñ‡Ñƒ Ğ¿Ñ€Ğ¾ Ğ¿Ğ¾ÑÑ‚Ğ¾ÑĞ½Ğ½Ñ‹Ğµ Ğ·Ğ°ÑÑ‚Ñ€ĞµĞ²Ğ°Ğ½Ğ¸Ñ Ğ¿Ñ€ĞµĞ´Ğ¼ĞµÑ‚Ğ¾Ğ² Ğ² Ñ‚ĞµĞºÑÑ‚ÑƒÑ€Ğ°Ñ…, Ğ½ĞµĞ²Ğ¾Ğ·Ğ¼Ğ¾Ğ¶Ğ½Ğ¾ÑÑ‚ÑŒ Ğ½Ğ¾Ñ€Ğ¼Ğ°Ğ»ÑŒĞ½Ğ¾ Ñ Ğ½Ğ¸Ğ¼Ğ¸ Ğ¿ĞµÑ€ĞµĞ´Ğ²Ğ¸Ğ³Ğ°Ñ‚ÑŒÑÑ (Ğ·Ğ° Ğ»Ğ¾ĞºĞ°Ñ†Ğ¸Ñ Ñ Ğ¼Ğ°Ğ³Ğ½Ğ¸Ñ‚Ğ½Ñ‹Ğ¼Ğ¸ Ğ´Ğ¾Ğ¼Ğ°Ğ¼Ğ¸ Ğ½Ğ°Ğ´Ğ¾ Ğ¾Ñ‚Ğ´ĞµĞ»ÑŒĞ½Ğ¾ Ğ²Ñ‹Ğ´Ğ°Ñ‚ÑŒ Ğ¿Ñ€ĞµĞ¼Ğ¸Ñ Ğ² Ğ¾Ğ±Ğ»Ğ°ÑÑ‚Ğ¸ Ğ¿ÑĞ¸Ñ…Ğ¾Ğ»Ğ¾Ğ³Ğ¸Ñ‡ĞµÑĞºĞ¾Ğ³Ğ¾ Ğ½Ğ°ÑĞ¸Ğ»Ğ¸Ñ Ğ½Ğ°Ğ´ Ğ¸Ğ³Ñ€Ğ¾ĞºĞ°Ğ¼Ğ¸) Ğ¸ Ğ¿Ñ€Ğ¾Ñ‡Ğ¸Ğµ Ñ‡Ñ‘Ñ€Ğ½Ñ‹Ğµ Ğ´Ñ‹Ñ€Ñ‹ Ğ¼ĞµÑÑ‚Ğ½Ğ¾Ğ³Ğ¾ Ğ³ĞµĞ¹Ğ¼Ğ´Ğ¸Ğ·Ğ°Ğ¹Ğ½Ğ°.

ĞÑƒĞ´Ğ¸Ğ¾Ğ²Ğ¸Ğ·ÑƒĞ°Ğ»ÑŒĞ½Ğ°Ñ Ñ‡Ğ°ÑÑ‚ÑŒ Ğ·Ğ´ĞµÑÑŒ â€“ Ğ²ĞµÑĞ¾Ğ¼Ğ°Ñ Ğ¿Ğ¾Ğ»Ğ¾Ğ¶Ğ¸Ñ‚ĞµĞ»ÑŒĞ½Ğ°Ñ ÑÑ‚Ğ¾Ñ€Ğ¾Ğ½Ğ°; Ğ¸Ğ³Ñ€Ğ° Ğ¾Ñ‡ĞµĞ½ÑŒ ĞºÑ€Ğ°ÑĞ¸Ğ²Ğ°Ñ Ğ² ÑĞ²Ğ¾ĞµĞ¹ Ğ´ĞµÑ‚Ğ°Ğ»Ğ¸Ğ·Ğ°Ñ†Ğ¸Ğ¸, Ñ†Ğ²ĞµÑ‚Ğ¾Ğ²Ñ‹Ñ… Ñ€ĞµÑˆĞµĞ½Ğ¸ÑÑ… Ğ¸ Ğ¸Ğ³Ñ€Ğ°Ñ… Ñ Ğ¼Ğ¸Ğ½Ğ¸Ğ¼Ğ°Ğ»Ğ¸Ğ·Ğ¼Ğ¾Ğ¼ Ğ¸ Ğ³Ğ¸Ğ³Ğ°Ğ½Ñ‚Ğ¸Ğ·Ğ¼Ğ¾Ğ¼ (Ğ¾ÑĞ¾Ğ±ĞµĞ½Ğ½Ğ¾ Ğ¼Ğ½Ğµ Ğ¿Ğ¾Ğ½Ñ€Ğ°Ğ²Ğ¸Ğ»ÑÑ Ğ¿Ğ¾Ğ´Ñ…Ğ¾Ğ´ Ğº Ğ´Ğ¸Ğ·Ğ°Ğ¹Ğ½Ñƒ Ñ€Ğ°ÑÑ‚ĞµĞ½Ğ¸Ğ¹, ĞµÑÑ‚ÑŒ Ñ‡ĞµĞ¼Ñƒ Ğ¿Ğ¾ÑƒÑ‡Ğ¸Ñ‚ÑŒÑÑ). ĞŸĞµÑĞ½Ğ¸ Ğ² ÑĞ°ÑƒĞ½Ğ´Ñ‚Ñ€ĞµĞºĞµ Ñ‚Ğ°ĞºĞ¶Ğµ Ğ¿Ğ¾Ğ´Ğ¾Ğ±Ñ€Ğ°Ğ½Ñ‹ Ğ¾Ñ‚Ğ»Ğ¸Ñ‡Ğ½Ğ¾ Ğ¸ Ğ·Ğ°Ğ´Ğ°ÑÑ‚ Ğ½Ğ°ÑÑ‚Ñ€Ğ¾ĞµĞ½Ğ¸Ğµ. ĞĞ´Ğ½Ğ°ĞºĞ¾ Ğ²ÑÑ‘ ÑÑ‚Ğ¾ Ğ½Ğµ Ğ¾Ñ‚Ğ¼ĞµĞ½ÑĞµÑ‚ Ñ„Ğ°ĞºÑ‚Ğ°, Ñ‡Ñ‚Ğ¾ Maquette â€“ ÑÑ‚Ğ¾ Ğ¾Ğ´Ğ½Ğ° Ğ¿Ğ¾Ñ‚ĞµĞ½Ñ†Ğ¸Ğ°Ğ»ÑŒĞ½Ğ¾ Ğ¸Ğ½Ñ‚ĞµÑ€ĞµÑĞ½Ğ°Ñ Ğ¼ĞµÑ…Ğ°Ğ½Ğ¸ĞºĞ°, ĞºĞ¾Ñ‚Ğ¾Ñ€Ğ¾Ğ¹ Ğ½Ğµ Ñ…Ğ²Ğ°Ñ‚Ğ¸Ğ»Ğ¾ Ğ±Ğ¾Ğ»ÑŒÑˆĞµ Ñ‡ĞµĞ¼ Ğ½Ğ° 2 Ñ‡Ğ°ÑĞ° Ğ¸Ğ³Ñ€Ñ‹. Ğ’Ğ¾Ñ‚ Ğ¸ Ğ¿Ñ€Ğ¸ÑˆĞ»Ğ¾ÑÑŒ Ğ·Ğ°Ğ±Ğ¸Ğ²Ğ°Ñ‚ÑŒ Ñ…Ñ€Ğ¾Ğ½Ğ¾Ğ¼ĞµÑ‚Ñ€Ğ°Ğ¶ ÑƒĞ½Ñ‹Ğ»Ñ‹Ğ¼Ğ¸ Ğ½ĞµÑĞ²ÑĞ·Ğ½Ñ‹Ğ¼Ğ¸ Ğ³Ğ¾Ğ»Ğ¾Ğ²Ğ¾Ğ»Ğ¾Ğ¼ĞºĞ°Ğ¼Ğ¸ Ğ¾Ñ‚ Ğ±Ğ°Ğ»Ğ´Ñ‹, Ñ…Ğ¾Ğ¶Ğ´ĞµĞ½Ğ¸ĞµĞ¼ Ñ‚ÑƒĞ´Ğ°-ÑÑĞ´Ğ° Ğ¸, Ñ‡Ñ‚Ğ¾ Ğ¾Ğ±Ğ¸Ğ´Ğ½ĞµĞµ Ğ²ÑĞµĞ³Ğ¾ â€“ Ğ¸ÑÑ‚Ğ¾Ñ€Ğ¸ĞµĞ¹, ĞºĞ¾Ñ‚Ğ¾Ñ€Ğ¾Ğ¹ ÑĞ¾Ğ²ĞµÑ€ÑˆĞµĞ½Ğ½Ğ¾ Ğ½ĞµÑ‡ĞµĞ¼ Ğ·Ğ°Ñ†ĞµĞ¿Ğ¸Ñ‚ÑŒ.

5 Ğ¸Ğ· 10 â€“ Ğ¿Ğ¾ÑÑ€ĞµĞ´ÑÑ‚Ğ²ĞµĞ½Ğ½Ğ¾
Ğ¡Ğ¿Ğ°ÑĞ¸Ğ±Ğ¾, Ñ‡Ñ‚Ğ¾ Ğ¿Ñ€Ğ¾Ñ‡Ğ»Ğ¸ ÑÑ‚Ğ¾Ñ‚ Ğ¾Ğ±Ğ·Ğ¾Ñ€! Ğ•ÑĞ»Ğ¸ Ğ½Ğµ Ñ‚Ñ€ÑƒĞ´Ğ½Ğ¾, Ğ¾Ñ†ĞµĞ½Ğ¸Ñ‚Ğµ, Ğ½Ğ°ÑĞºĞ¾Ğ»ÑŒĞºĞ¾ Ğ¾Ğ½ Ğ±Ñ‹Ğ» Ğ²Ğ°Ğ¼ Ğ¿Ğ¾Ğ»ĞµĞ·ĞµĞ½, Ğ¸ Ğ¼Ğ¾Ğ¶ĞµÑ‚Ğµ Ğ¿Ğ¾ÑĞ¼Ğ¾Ñ‚Ñ€ĞµÑ‚ÑŒ Ğ´Ñ€ÑƒĞ³Ğ¸Ğµ Ğ¾Ğ±Ğ·Ğ¾Ñ€Ñ‹ Ğ² Ğ¼Ğ¾Ñ‘Ğ¼ Ğ¿Ñ€Ğ¾Ñ„Ğ¸Ğ»Ğµ ;)

P.S. Ğ•ÑĞ»Ğ¸ Ğ²Ğ°Ğ¼ Ğ¿Ğ¾ĞºĞ°Ğ¶ĞµÑ‚ÑÑ Ğ¼Ğ°Ğ»Ğ¾ Ğ¿Ñ€Ğ¾Ğ±Ğ»ĞµĞ¼ Ñ ÑƒĞ¿Ñ€Ğ°Ğ²Ğ»ĞµĞ½Ğ¸ĞµĞ¼, Ğ²Ğ°Ñ ÑƒÑĞ¿ĞµÑˆĞ½Ğ¾ Ğ´Ğ¾ĞºĞ¾Ğ½Ğ°ÑÑ‚ Ğ±Ğ°Ğ³Ğ¸ â€“ Ğ·Ğ°Ğ²Ğ¸ÑĞ°Ğ½Ğ¸Ñ ÑƒÑ€Ğ¾Ğ²Ğ½ĞµĞ¹, Ğ½Ğµ ÑÑ€Ğ°Ğ±Ğ°Ñ‚Ñ‹Ğ²Ğ°ÑÑ‰Ğ¸Ğµ ÑĞºÑ€Ğ¸Ğ¿Ñ‚Ñ‹, Ğ¿Ñ€Ğ¾Ğ¿Ğ°Ğ´Ğ°ÑÑ‰Ğ¸Ğµ Ğ´Ğ¸Ğ°Ğ»Ğ¾Ğ³Ğ¸ Ğ¸ Ğ¿Ñ€Ğ¾Ñ‡Ğ¸Ğµ Ğ¿Ñ€ĞµĞ»ĞµÑÑ‚Ğ¸.

Ã‰valuation publiÃ©e le 2 mars 2021
This game is absolutely beautiful, challenging to a comfortable degree and very elegant with its story and atmosphere with a top notch selection of music. But I find it to be a bit short. I completed it within 2.6 hours while also taking my time (bathroom breaks etc).
Would I recommend this game? Absolutely although id suggest getting it once its on a considerable sale. Otherwise its a beautiful game id love to see have future installments with a lot more gameplay time.

8 personnes ont trouvÃ© cette Ã©valuation amusante

Non recommandÃ©
2.8 h en tout
Ã‰valuation publiÃ©e le 6 mars 2021
: "Things were starting out so well! I saw an exciting new puzzle game billed as mix of Superliminal and Florence. The game and I really hit it off. The visuals were gorgeous, the music was setting up the right vibe, the puzzles were clever and the story was starting out as a sketch worthy of a Pixar short.

But after a while the cracks started to show. Long backtracking sections that weren't appropriately filled with new dialogue. Quirky controls began to actively fight me. Bugs crept in, making me abandon two savegames. At the same time the story began to deteriorate into another account of a shallow relationship falling apart because it wasn't held together by anything beyond the desire to feel good.

This downward shift in quality of the experience came in sync with the unfolding story to such a meta degree, that for a split second I was honestly expecting the game to break the final wall and have Michael play Maquette on the laptop in that one scene. Perhaps his review would start like this: "Things were starting out so well! I saw an exciting new indie game...
 
Monodon

3 personnes ont trouvÃ© cette Ã©valuation amusante
1
Non recommandÃ©
3.8 h en tout
Ã‰valuation publiÃ©e le 22 mai 2021
Four full hours of holding W with around four moments that might require you stop pressing W for long enough to see how the dog fits in the dog-shaped-hole. The core mechanics is so criminally unexplored that I felt genuine sadness to see it so underutilized, emotions stronger than anything the bland story ever hopes to invoke at you. The controls feel like wrestling a bag full of wild badgers and fact that the shift button slows you down instead of speeding you up might as well have been a practical joke.

The music is good, the game looks pretty most of the time and the core gameplay concept is something that I really hope gets explored in the future but as it stands now, I cannot recommend this game

ä½ ç©¶ç«Ÿä¸ºäº†å“ªäº›ç©å®¶åˆ¶ä½œè§£å¯†ï¼Œæ˜¯åˆ¶ä½œè€…çš„å®šä½ï¼Œä½†ä½ è®©ç©å®¶è¿‡ä¸å»äº†ï¼Œè¿™å°±æ˜¯æ— æ³•åŸè°…çš„äº‹æƒ…ã€‚

dogsamaç‹—å“¥

1 personne a trouvÃ© cette Ã©valuation amusante

RecommandÃ©

Ã‰valuation publiÃ©e le 26 mars 2021
Produit reÃ§u gratuitement

Maquette

Maquetteâ€™s unusual and mind-bending puzzles will have you thinking outside the box. Game mechanics can be a little frustrating and the story is a little bland but well performed.

See all my reviews at Indie Blast! or check out my You Tube channel HERE

Maquette is a first person puzzle game centered around three models of a town.

Each town is different in size and you can move between these different sized models solving various puzzles. Each town is connected and objects in one town are replicated in other towns but in different sizes.

Your goal is to navigate out of the seven areas, each representing a stage of their relationship.

Story ğŸ“•
Michael and Kenzie meet and instantly a spark is created.

What follows is a relationship in bloom and we watch as events unfold, chronicling the ups and downs of their relationship together.

The attraction started through their love of drawing and by solving puzzles within the Maquette, we see how the relationship evolves through hand drawn pictures and voice overs.

The small Maquette, surrounded by the medium Maquette, surrounded by the large Maquette. You can move in-between all three. 
Une capture d'Ã©cran de Maquette
Par : janner66


Overall ImpressionsğŸ¤”

Maquette is a bit of a mixed bag and I would say its current mixed rating is about right. It is going to appeal to some people and not to others.

I found the puzzles to be quite difficult. Some of them are extremely clever and do provide you with immense satisfaction when you finally work them out. Others, seem unfair or have their own set of rules which you are not privy to.

The puzzles in Maquette are never explained. It isnâ€™t as bad as The Witness for example, but the game leans in that direction. You are dropped into a scene and it is up to you to work out what to do and where to go. There are visual clues, and sometimes it is obvious, but other times the solutions seem nonsensical.

The game at times encourages exploration but then blocks your passage; doesnâ€™t let you drop items when there is no reason it should; the smaller Maquette can be painfully claustrophobic and awkward to place objects and the walking speed in the large Maquette is very slow. The game can be quite frustrating at times.

The majority of the puzzles are clever, if a bit awkward to navigate. Puzzles are mostly solved by using objects which have to be rotated into place. The camera and the surrounding structures can prove troublesome but with perseverance it can be done.

For some reason, my Xbox one wireless controller caused the game to lag severely although the developers said they hadnâ€™t had this issue reported. I had to use the keyboard and mouse which wasnâ€™t my first choice.

The graphics are pleasant. The cut scenes are gradually sketched, like someone drawing the scene until it is completed. This was nice to see and well done.

The voice overs are very professional and emotional. The story is just a typical relationship. It wasnâ€™t particularly dramatic or memorable. The songs felt a bit out of place and would sometimes randomly kick in at inappropriate times. I think music could have been used better.

If you are an achievement hunter then a third of the achievements are speed runs which I am not even going to bother with. I can only see that ending in tears!


Maquette will appeal to fans of The Witness or puzzle enthusiasts who like to think outside the box. The puzzles are ambiguous and the rules need to be established before you can solve the puzzle.

The game mechanics can be a little frustrating as you are often navigating in tight areas but it isnâ€™t bad enough to put anyone off.

I was a little disappointed with the story. It was pleasant, and the chapters representing their life together was neat, but the story was rather bland and forgetful.

Iâ€™d pick this up in a sale if it appeals to you.

GameplayğŸ•¹ï¸

VidÃ©o YouTubeâ„¢: Maquette PC Gameplay 
Vues : 9
9 Minute video PC game footage Maquetteâ€™s unusual and mind-bending puzzles will have you thinking outside the box. Game mechanics can be a little frustrating and the story is a little bland but well...


A Maquette is a model. The Maquette represents their kinship; where they met; memorable moments and past events.
There are three Maquettes and each model represents a different size.

By moving objects in and out of each model we can affect the object size and placing objects in one model will be replicated in the other two models but either smaller or bigger. If you drop an object in one model you can often see its bigger or smaller counterpart falling in another model in the distance.

The game is a three dimensional puzzle game where size matters!

By moving in and out of each three-dimensional model it feels like you are getting bigger or smaller, whereas in fact it is just the environment which has changed. You may no longer be able to climb stairs for example, as they are now too large.

The objects in the large Maquette are too big to pick up but objects in the normal and small Maquette can be picked up, rotated and dropped almost anywhere. So, by placing an object on the stairs in the small or normal Maquette could possibly mean you could climb that object in the large Maquette and get up the stairs you previously could not climb.

Walking speeds are affected depending on which model you are in. The large Maquette means you walk painfully slow sometimes, and some environments are quite big so this can take some time.

There are no indicators as to where to go or what to do but there are sometimes subtle hints to guide you in the right direction. Some butterflies flying around a door; a coloured gem; or colour coded doors are all examples of visual hints.

Mostly, you will just be trying to enter buildings to trigger small cut scenes of relationship moments. Along the way, you will see comments by Michael or Kenzie in the form of floating sentences, describing their feelings at the time.

Cut scenes and voice overs narrate events in their relationship. The pictures are drawn and coloured gradually until completed. 
Une capture d'Ã©cran de Maquette
Par : janner66


Graphics ğŸ“º
The visuals are okay. They look bright and cheerful. The cut scenes are nicely done by gradually drawing the scene as it unravels, as if they are drawing a sketch of an event.

Sound ğŸµ
There are odd sporadic cases of songs bursting into the game. Sometimes, they make sense and add emotional weight to the story but sometimes they feel out of place and distracting. The songs are performed well enough but Iâ€™m just not sure they add to the experience.

The object noises as they drop sound awesome. When you hear a massive key drop in the distance it sounds weighty and satisfying.

ConclusionğŸ³
Maquette is a tough puzzle game if youâ€™re not used to thinking three dimensionally or looking at things in a different way.

It definitely sits in â€œThe Witnessâ€ camp. It can be quite cryptic and obscure.

The puzzles solutions can feel very rewarding when that final eureka moment hits you but the bland story is stark reward for your achievements.
 
janner66
9,315 produits enregistrÃ©s
14
27 personnes ont trouvÃ© cette Ã©valuation utile
3 personnes ont trouvÃ© cette Ã©valuation amusante
1
Non recommandÃ©
15.8 h en tout
Ã‰valuation publiÃ©e le 18 mars 2021
A good game, but not worth $20.
I haven't kept up with this game much after the initial announcement but after seeing how cool it looked I decided to blind buy it.
What I didn't realize is that this isn't really a puzzle game so much as the game is a medium to tell a love story.
That's fine because other games like Edith Finch/Story About My Uncle have done this great, but my god I have not felt this disappointed in a long time.
I expected some loose story to go with this game about wacky mindbending puzzles and I got the complete opposite.
There's ~7 levels and maybe 4-6 "puzzles" per level, and a lot of them are "use this object to make a bridge" kind of thing.
The puzzles are cool and surprisingly intuitive but the recursion mechanic is criminally underutilized.
There's only 3 real recursions you explore: Small, Big, Default. It's very apparent why they did this, because in the bigger worlds
your movement speed is aggravatingly slow and terrible. Rather than find a solution for that, they kind of boxed you in with your mobility and ability to solve puzzles in your own way.
If an object is too small, you can't grab it, there's only maybe 1-2 objects for you to use at a time, it really feels like they kept the baby gloves on for you.

The gameplay does reflect the story in an interesting way sometimes, and some of the puzzles are really clever, but there's so few of them that not only am I left wanting more, I am thinking "That's it???"
The amount of puzzles per level is so small for how big they are, I never felt like I really finished a level.
THIS IS NOT A PUZZLE GAME, THIS IS A STORY GAME TOLD THROUGH THE LENSE OF A PUZZLE GAME. If the story was better maybe it could be justified, but I can't help but have a bitter taste from how cool and original of a mechanic this is and how they really wasted that on 10 puzzles.
As with most games like this, it only gets interesting and difficult near the end for some reason the last half hour of the game is filled with fantastic, creative, out of the box puzzles.
It's heartbreaking to play, not just becuase of the story, but because the better the puzzles get, the closer you know you're getting to the end. Really a tease.
The game doesn't let you solve things your own way or explore more than the breadcrumb trail they left for you, which I believe is in service to the accesibility of the story and detriment of the gameplay.
The biggest example of this is that sometimes you can hold an object and it will fit in a hole in the regular world, and you should be able to just grab it and place it, but the game says NO, you have to go to the small world and place the same object there, even though they are the exact same scale. There's a lack of room of outside solutions.

This is a, good-ish game though. If you liked other games in this style you'll probably enjoy this for the experience, it's got nice music, the level design and puzzle design is intuitive and interesting.
Surprisingly you won't feel lost, you're in a big plus sign and each arm has different environments. The recursion even gives you a little miniature world to look at and kind of use as your map in the hub.
The recursion engine is really impressive in the later levels, the feeling of seeing a giant version of the object your holding in the distance is a really cool feeling the first time.
I hate how short this game is, because it is really fun thinking with this mechanic and trying new things out, I would love to do more with it because the gameplay really is fun and solid. If you loved other story based games then you'd probably enjoy this, the story isn't as compelling as other games but it's nice and the game is pretty and cool to play. For someone expecting a little bit more out of this game, you won't find it.

I strongly believe that there are enough mechanics here to make a really good, compelling, challenging game and I'm really disappointed that it was so underutilized especially since now there's not going to be a game with this mechanic in a while because then everyone will way "they copied Maquette".
That said, it isn't a terrible game, just when the lens of context is applied to it, it doesn't stand up to the hype it creates for itself.

It's really strange that all these games are popping up with such similar "vibes" to them, I'm not sure if it's really a genre or just a new style that is being adopted. It's cool when used sparingly, but I think this one missed the mark.
 
Goblin
10

Ã‰valuation publiÃ©e le 3 mars 2021
Ehhhh....

Overall I feel Superliminal is the better perspective-based puzzle overall. I think this one is prettier, but it is more a walking sim than a puzzle game. It also has a better message IMO? Superliminal ends with more optimism and a creative message, whereas this is just 500 Days of Summer down to the "quirky" name of the female character. Are we supposed to be siding with the guy who narrates? He's unbearable.

It was a good short puzzle but not worth the price.
 
katsumeragi
429 produits enregistrÃ©s
0
27 personnes ont trouvÃ© cette Ã©valuation utile
3 personnes ont trouvÃ© cette Ã©valuation amusante
0
Non recommandÃ©
2.9 h en tout
Ã‰valuation publiÃ©e le 5 fÃ©vrier 2023
Overall: 4/10, mostly from the milquetoast story and the frequent yanking of the controls for lame slow pan cutscenes.

First of all, wonderful concept. Shame that the story is so bland. Like chicken seasoned with water. The perspective of the storytelling feels like the standard fare of sad guy who has a bunch of red flag behavior and eventually has his relationship deteriorate for... people growing apart? Frankly, a lot of what Michael says early on in the relationship is like a big cry for help to go to therapy, and since the perspective is solely his we only see his flaws. Which makes me wonder what the hell their chemistry is supposed to be. Seriously, he downplays her constantly and basically isolates her with his anxiety.

Okay but enough about the story and how it feels like a 1st year college student journal, let's talk about the game. The game has...some great puzzles. Key word, some. What holds back a majority of the puzzles is the god awful move speed, which is only slightly noticeable in normal sized sections but horrendously slow when you are smaller than the environment. There are some hidden, inconsistent speed boost pads beneath the floor in some places, but frankly its not enough to make a failed puzzle solution feel any less punishing to trudge back through. Additionally, the environmental indicators are dodgy, leading to some stumped moments because the cues are not there to get you to pay attention to the right spot. Finally, there are sooo many opportunities to soft lock yourself, despite the game trying its best to not let you drop something in a location you can't retrieve it. Lookin' at you, gear and red orb section.

Frankly, the thing I can absolutely recommend about this game are the visuals. Absolutely stunning imagery throughout, only marred by frequent interrupting cutscenes that yank your ability to appreciate the moving parts and changing environments, often heavy handedly pointing you to an important thing rather than letting environmental cues guide you there.

In summary, I would recommend this game on hefty discount, as the sparse, phenomenal puzzles and fantastic visual design are undercut by the lukewarm main character, what the textbooks tell you to avoid story, dodgy guidance, sluggish controls, and mechanics that never really bloom into something interesting. What I can say to really wrap the game up in a neat bow is that everything in the game is simply a set piece, with no depth or stability keeping it interesting or smooth.

And don't get me started on the bugs, glitches, and performance issues. I walked on a pile of wood and it flipped a switch halfway across the map for me.
 
EldoradoNights
269 produits enregistrÃ©s
0
22 personnes ont trouvÃ© cette Ã©valuation utile
0
Non recommandÃ©
4.8 h en tout
Ã‰valuation publiÃ©e le 6 juillet 2022
This game is a mixed bag, and honestly not one I would recommend to anyone I actually liked.

First, the good:
- It's beautiful, and has nice animations and music to go along with the pretty visuals.

Now the bad:
- The puzzles are trivial for the most part.
- Most puzzle mechanics are one and done. The crystals used to open doors exist for a single level before disappearing entirely. At no point does the game seriously make an attempt to challenge the player by mixing the mechanics, or adding greater complexity to existing mechanics such as more than 1 level of nesting to the Maquette.
- Puzzles mostly boil down to, resize the thing, use it as a bridge, then get to the maguffin.
- Player movement is fairly slow which is alright at normal scale but painful at small scale. A sprint button would be appreciated.
- Options involving multiple different nested maquettes are ignored.
- The story is mediocre, but fails to meaningfully connect with the puzzle solving you are actually doing.

Now, the ugly:
- The player character handles like dead fish. Controls for picking things up and dropping them fail to give you much precision, while forcing a slow mode on you during placement. When running into a wall with an object, the game will attempt to maintain the distance you have selected between yourself and the object by turning your view around.
- Bugs. In the final level, attempting to pick up the maquette while standing on it, or on the lip will result in an instant crash.
- The timed puzzle has a chance of completely bugging out and not opening the door requiring a level reset to try and make progress.
- The key resizing puzzle can cause confusion due to small keys sinking into the floor of the very large room that the maquettes are mirroring. Combined with the poor lighting in the room, it can make it close to impossible to to find the key in the room.

In summary: The game is pretty and well acted, but has no depth, few good puzzles, clunky controls, and weak integration between the story and the game-play. The game has multiple bugs, some of which are not immediately obvious to the player which completely lock off progression.

Not recommended.
 
Centurion902
0
19 personnes ont trouvÃ© cette Ã©valuation utile
0
RecommandÃ©
4.4 h en tout
Ã‰valuation publiÃ©e le 11 juillet 2021
For those whoe wanna check it out but concerned about the "MIXED" reviews.
i must say. i came for the puzzles but stay for the plot,

Yes, at the core the game doesnt push the boundaries of this brilliant idea of a world into a world.
Yes, the story may be a little cliche.
yes, they should improve the item locking and the use of the mouse.
and yes it did crashed a like 3 times towards the end.

BUT. its a debut game guys.
which finally brings something new to the table.
the story its not just a love story, its about growing up, overcoming.
the complexity of the world that maquette brings to us, its equivalent as the complexity in each human being and how we develop according to the challenges we are introduce in the course of life.
the game gets slower and harder at the moment the characters are experiencing the same. that was huge for me. i think its a great detail.
the music is great, the voice acting too.

it is for sure a game to recommend.

Un peu plus de 5 heures de durÃ©e de vie.
Comme le montre le trailer, le concept des Ã©nigmes est basÃ© sur la rÃ©cursivitÃ© et le changement d'Ã©chelles.
Je pense qu'il aurait Ã©tÃ© possible d'offrir plus d'Ã©nigmes sur ce concept, avec plus d'objets notamment. Le jeu brosse toutes les facettes possibles, mais sans forcÃ©ment les approfondir. Dommage, car il y avait des mÃ©caniques intÃ©ressantes, surtout celles vers la fin.

L'histoire amoureuse en trame de fond narrative ne m'a pas forcÃ©ment conquise, je trouvais que Ã§a s'intÃ©grait pas forcÃ©ment avec le game design. On aurait aimÃ© en avoir plus tant le principe vendait du rÃªve.

C'est une expÃ©rience courte, mais sympathique, un peu comme Rime.
Superliminal reste au-dessus.

16 personnes ont trouvÃ© cette Ã©valuation utile
1 personne a trouvÃ© cette Ã©valuation amusante
0
Non recommandÃ©
4.5 h en tout
Ã‰valuation publiÃ©e le 7 mars 2021
This game felt very "meh" to me. I typically like short games, I prefer short games with a bang over 80 hour epics In Which You Can Do Anything And Go Anywhere.

However, I did not enjoy my time with this game:
- The "story" (I guess it's more of an audio book that you listen to while you play the game) is pretty clichee: Guy meets girl, falls in love, they move together, they fight, the break up. Literally the end.
- The "Twist" is spoiled in the trailer, although I guess that's how you get people to buy this game
- The game feels unfinished: Lots of invisible walls; there is somehow too much and too little handholding at the same time: If you miss the hint, you can wander around aimlessly for hours, turning every stone, wondering which of the things you can even interact with, until afterwards you realize that, oh, the thing you thought was gonna "Be it" from the very start, in fact "Was It", and it only didn't work due to janky controls/physics
- The mechanic of "The Twist" is interesting, but IMHO barely explored properly

Like, I don't want to be too harsh, I can tell the developers tried, but... It just kinda wasn't good enough for me.
 
HaiZhung

Ã‰valuation publiÃ©e le 2 mars 2021
Produit reÃ§u gratuitement

Maquette - Review

Como suele ser habitual, toda historia de amor comienza â™¥â™¥â™¥ un buen cafÃ©, y la obra de Graceful Decay no iba a ser la excepciÃ³n. En Maquette exploramos la escala de los problemas cotidianos en una floreciente relacion donde los dilemas, por mÃ¡s minÃºsculos que parezcan, implican obstÃ¡culos que conllevan a duros roces. No es una premisa del todo empalagosa, sino que desarrolla las etapas de una relaciÃ³n. En este caso la de Michael y Kenzie, dos jÃ³venes que han comenzado a experimentar el amor â™¥â™¥â™¥ una gran intensidad. Como suele ser habitual en los â€œromancesâ€ la premisa pocas veces deja lugar para la imaginaciÃ³n, pues, gira sobre tÃ³picos demasiado evidentes y previsibles. Lamentablemente, Maquette cae en ese bucle, y la historia de Michael y Kenzie es otra mÃ¡s del montÃ³n, un drama que no termina de encender la chispa, por lo tanto, el relato se diluye en un amargo rio de sentimentalismo, es decir, no maneja del todo bien los tiempos por lo que sus cambios de escena se sienten demasiados bruscos. Pasar de estar felices a orillas del mar para dibujar el agotamiento mental de una rutina al otro dÃ­a, no es del todo acertada. No construye la emociÃ³n de sus personajes y esto se traduce en un relato agridulce. No tiene la naturalidad de RiME o Arise a Simple Story, que funcionan de principio a fin como un viaje de crecimiento personal. Maquette lo intenta, sin Ã©xito alguno.

Eso no quita que como â€œjuegoâ€, sea una autÃ©ntica maravilla. El sistema recursivo al estilo M.C. Esther, (un mundo de paradojas visuales), le sienta de maravilla y da lugar a ideas alocadas â™¥â™¥â™¥ rompecabezas ambientales bastante ingeniosos, que exprimirÃ¡n al mÃ¡ximo las neuronas. Al fin al cabo, en sus inicios el elemento â€œRecursivoâ€ sonaba innecesariamente complicado, quizÃ¡s mÃ¡s de lo necesario, pues se presta para explicaciones confusas. Sin embargo, en la prÃ¡ctica es todo lo contrario, tal y como sucedÃ­a â™¥â™¥â™¥ Superliminal de Pillow Castle, es decir, la escala se convierte en una mecÃ¡nica de juego y tendremos que pensar por fuera de la caja para resolver los perspicaces rompecabezas que encontraremos en aquella pintoresca maqueta.

Cabe destacar que el mundo de Maquette toma mÃºltiples formas en cada uno de sus seis episodios por lo que ira evolucionando las tÃ©cnicas recursivas para no estancarse en lo tradicional de â€œachicarâ€ o â€œagrandarâ€ objetos, sino que cada tanto le da una vuelta de tuerca para romper la cuarta pared y darle un soplo de aire fresco a sus interminables â€œmundo de miniaturaâ€ o de â€œtamaÃ±o normalâ€. A su vez, todos ellos conviven en un â€œDomo Centralâ€ y desde allÃ­ podremos experimentar â™¥â™¥â™¥ los objetos para obtener resultados minÃºsculos o gigantes, pues, cada una de sus maquetas, y por consecuente, los elementos que predominan en su interior, funciona como una rÃ©plica exacta. Esta es una idea recurrente al vincular un solo objeto en ambos mundos para utilizarlos de diferentes modos. Por lo tanto, funciona como el aleteo de una mariposa, cada acciÃ³n que realicemos en una zona genera una variante en el otro mundo.

â™¥â™¥â™¥ el amor de fondo, Maquette inicia un apasionante viaje de melancolÃ­a por las memorias fragmentadas de una joven pareja para resolver â™¥â™¥â™¥ mucha prudencia el mayor rompecabezas de todos, el amor. La obra de Graceful Decay tiene una absurda dosis de originalidad debido a su temÃ¡tica recursiva que hace y deshace su propia maqueta como si se tratase de un castillo de naipes dentro de un laberinto de cristales. El manejo de las escalas para representar sutilmente la disparidad de una relaciÃ³n funcionaâ€¦ a medias. Esto se debe a una narrativa algo floja â™¥â™¥â™¥ cambios de escena demasiado bruscos y un inexistente vÃ­nculo entre lo que vemos y hacemos. A diferencia de Arise a Simple Story que canaliza todo su poder narrativo en la jugabilidad para dejar que sus rompecabezas hablen por sÃ­ mismo. Maquette baraja este concepto, pero â™¥â™¥â™¥ resultados un tanto agridulces. AÃºn asÃ­, ante todo, es un juego de rompecabezas, y estos se le dan muy bien.

Sin lugar a dudas, una asignatura pendiente para cualquier fanÃ¡tico de los FPP, quizÃ¡s un tanto repetitivo, pero un juego que no deberÃ­a pasar desapercibido.

Puntos Positivos

*El concepto recursivo para dar vida a sus escenarios.
*Visualmente luce muy bien.
*Mecanicas originales e interesantes.
*Ell Voice Acting tiene un nivel de calidad importante.
*Apartado sonoro bien cuidado, que acompaÃ±a acordemente cada memoria.
*Soporte para resoluciones ultra-panoramicas.
*Un drama que se sigue â™¥â™¥â™¥ interÃ©sâ€¦.

Puntos Negativos

*Pero deja un sabor agridulce.
*Una opciÃ³n para correr no le harÃ­a ningÃºn mal.
*La interaccion â™¥â™¥â™¥ objetos tiende a ser tosca e imprecisa.
*Ciertos bloqueos artificiales que conllevan a re-iniciar la partida o cargar el ultimo punto de guardado.
*No existe una conexiÃ³n clara entre â€œlo que vemosâ€ y â€œhacemosâ€

Para leer el analisis completo dirigirse al siguiente enlace:

PC Indie Master Race [pcindiemrace.com]
 
MadMax
2,452 produits enregistrÃ©s
0
14 personnes ont trouvÃ© cette Ã©valuation utile
1 personne a trouvÃ© cette Ã©valuation amusante
1
Non recommandÃ©
0.9 h en tout
Ã‰valuation publiÃ©e le 8 mars 2021
It's very limited. If you have played The Witness you'll know how this feels: You start to understand the mechanics taught to you and the game starts to open up a little. But then you try applying interesting puzzle solutions yourself, and the game punishes you for not finding the hints in the exact order it was designed. There is no space for you to puzzle in this puzzle game. I tried to shrink objects down to molecular size - not allowed. I tried to shrink myself down to fit through small holes - not allowed. I tried to place large objects in such a way that they form bridges over walls - not allowed, unless intended.

There are some pretty clever ideas where an object has multiple purposes at different scales, but that is all that this puzzle gimmick entails. They stapled some tired love story to it and suddenly expect me to get invested? The gameplay has nothing to do with love, and the success of other puzzle games is a clear indication that you shouldn't need the story. This game could just have been a genuine puzzle game but instead environments are stretched out and dialogue is scattered throughout. Techniques are not expanded upon and the game quickly feels like a hunt for the one clue you missed. You start to think "What would the designer have intended for me to see" instead of "What can I do with the tools at my disposal." Again, not puzzling but just... intentionally having your hand held.

Plain bad executions, sadly.
 
Loeka
179 produits enregistrÃ©s
0
14 personnes ont trouvÃ© cette Ã©valuation utile
1
Non recommandÃ©
4.5 h en tout
Ã‰valuation publiÃ©e le 2 juin 2022
Maquette

positive:
  • beautiful artstyle
  • atmospheric
  • cool puzzle concept (very similar to Superliminal)
  • decent voice acting

negative:
  • clunky and unintuitive controls
  • boring narrative
  • uninteresting gameplay
  • easy to break the game
  • a little short
  • several crashes in the last level
  • speedrun achievements (unacceptable with said flaws)

â˜ å°¼ç›åˆ«çœ‹è¯„æµ‹äº†ï¼Œèµ¶ç´§å»ç©ï¼ä»€ä¹ˆï¼Œå¤§æ¸…äº¡äº†ï¼Ÿç°åœ¨å…¬å…ƒå‡ å‡ å¹´ï¼Ÿ
â˜ åˆ·åˆ·åˆ·ï¼Œbiubiubiuï¼Œçªçªçªâ€¦â€¦

13 personnes ont trouvÃ© cette Ã©valuation utile
1 personne a trouvÃ© cette Ã©valuation amusante
0
RecommandÃ©
5.8 h en tout
Ã‰valuation publiÃ©e le 28 mai 2022
Maquette falls into that increasingly-common category of games with a creative puzzle mechanic that's tied together by a story with a heavy theme. (See also: Monocage, Braid, It Takes Two, RiME, The Unfinished Swan, Superliminal, A Fisherman's Tale, Gorogoa, et cetera.)
I found the story parts difficult to listen to, but not because they're bad in any sense: they're well-written and voiced, and mesh with the puzzles and level design in meaningful ways. You can skip cutscenes by holding spacebar, but I don't think you should (until you're ready to take a crack at the speedrun achievements anyway).
It's fairly short: I completed the story in around 4 hours, then took another hour or so to complete the speedrun achievements.
The core puzzle mechanic itself is unique, and each stage riffs on it in different ways, which combines with the game's short length to ensure the puzzles never have a chance to feel stale or tedious.
 
ReverendTed
0

1 personne a trouvÃ© cette Ã©valuation amusante
0
RecommandÃ©
3.5 h en tout
Ã‰valuation publiÃ©e le 2 mars 2021
â€Um die Ecke denkenâ€œ mal anders
Maquette ist in erster Linie ein First-Person-Puzzle-Spiel, welches als Rahmenhandlung die Liebesgeschichte zwischen Kenzie und Michael erzÃ¤hlt. Nach der EinfÃ¼hrung befinden wir uns in einem â€Raumâ€œ, in dessen Mitte wir unseren â€Raumâ€œ nochmals als Miniatur sehen und in dessen Miniatur kann man wiederum eine Miniatur der Miniatur erkennen, etc. ... Genau das gleiche ist darÃ¼ber hinaus auch genau umgekehrt zu sehen ... sprich wenn wir aus unserem â€Raumâ€œ heraus sehen, sehen wir eine XL-Variante davon und dieser wiederum zeigt abermals eine XL-Variante, etc. ... Und in all dem stehen wir.

Das besondere ist nun, dass wenn wir einen Gegenstand in einer der Welten bewegen, dieser auch automatisch in den Ã¼brigen Welten bewegt wird - in der ursprÃ¼nglichen Original-AusgangsgrÃ¶ÃŸe. Haben wir also einen handlichen SchlÃ¼ssel in der Hand, dann ist dieser in der Miniatur natÃ¼rlich riesig und entsprechend fÃ¤llt dann auch in unserer Welt ein SchlÃ¼ssel vom Himmel, so groÃŸ wie ein LKW. Das mag zunÃ¤chst kompliziert klingen, aber man findet sich recht zÃ¼gig in die Grundlagen ein. AnschlieÃŸend gilt es dann, diese immer wieder neu zu verbiegen, um diverse RÃ¤tsel zu lÃ¶sen. Der Schwierigkeitsgrad zieht dabei angenehm an.

Bisher habe ich die ersten beiden Kapitel abgeschlossen und musste im zweiten bereits einiges mehr an Hirnschmalz aufwenden, wohingegen das erste noch locker von der Hand ging. RÃ¤tselfreunde kommen hier definitiv auf ihre Kosten.

PrÃ¤sentation
Ãœblicherweise spreche ich zunÃ¤chst die Grafik an, jedoch heute mÃ¶chte ich einfach den genialen Soundtrack hervorheben. Bereits in den ersten Minuten gibt es wunderbare Musik auf die Ohren und dies wiederholt sich mit immer neuen Tracks wÃ¤hrend des Spielverlaufs. Ich mÃ¶chte bitte den Soundtrack haben. :D

DarÃ¼ber hinaus ist auch die Grafik sehr farbenfroh gehalten und kommt in einer Cell-Shading-artigen Optik daher. Dies erlaubt wunderschÃ¶ne Kulissen, welche zwar nicht Ã¼bermÃ¤ÃŸig stark detailliert sind aber auch nicht langweilen.

Auch sehr gut hat mir die Sprachausgabe der zwei Hauptfiguren gefallen â€“ sehr professionell und natÃ¼rlich. Wenn ich mich nicht tÃ¤usche, habe ich irgendwo gelesen, dass die beiden Sprecher tatsÃ¤chlich ein Paar im echten Leben sind und das merkt man auch, wenn man ihnen zuhÃ¶rt. Wirklich toll.

Fazit:
Spieler, die von Titeln wie â€Superliminalâ€œ begeistert waren, aber auch alle sonstigen RÃ¤tselfreunde, denen mal wieder der Kopf qualmen soll, finde hier sicher eine Menge SpaÃŸ und Training fÃ¼r die eigenen Gehirnwindungen und obendrauf noch eine wunderschÃ¶n erzÃ¤hlte Liebesgeschichte. Definitiv eine Empfehlung von mir.

Non recommandÃ©
3.6 h en tout
Ã‰valuation publiÃ©e le 27 octobre 2022
Maquette entrega uma frustrante proporÃ§Ã£o entre diversÃ£o e irritaÃ§Ã£o!

Em meus comentÃ¡rios, sempre fiz questÃ£o de exaltar como a Annapurna Interactive Ã© uma das melhores e mais valiosas distribuidoras de jogos da atualidade. Voltando suas lentes para a criatividade de seus parceiros, a empresa sempre esteve focada em dar oportunidades para experiÃªncias diversificadas que satisfaÃ§am seu pÃºblico alvo, apostando em jogos que tragam ideias novas para um mercado tÃ£o saturado. Maquette, por sua vez, traz consigo uma premissa forte, ao apresentar um pequeno playground formado por maquetes que podemos utilizar para modificar o ambiente. Ao alterar algo na maquete menor, essa mudanÃ§a tambÃ©m refletirÃ¡ na maquete maior, o que Ã© a chave para a resoluÃ§Ã£o de seus quebra-cabeÃ§as. Brincando com essas ideias, poderemos utilizar essas proporÃ§Ãµes ao nosso favor, transitando objetos especÃ­ficos ao logo do cenÃ¡rio para avanÃ§ar em cada desafio e completar essa curta jornada. Entretanto, visto que Superliminal jÃ¡ tinha mostrado esse recurso de proporcionalidade de uma forma exemplar, alÃ©m de inÃºmeros outros jogos jÃ¡ terem apresentado ideias semelhantes, era preciso que Maquette apresentasse novas possibilidades dentro dessa mecÃ¢nica, diferenciando-se em meio aos seus concorrentes e consolidando a si mesmo como um novo clÃ¡ssico dos puzzles.

Dito isto, eu preciso admitir... Maquette entrega um show de inventividade impressionante! Esbanjando puzzles bem planejados de uma forma que instiga e convida o jogador para imaginar as possibilidades que seu design proporciona, a Graceful Decay, desenvolvedora da obra, conseguiu implementar esse sistema de proporcionalidade de uma forma genuinamente interessante e divertida de se explorar. Alterar o tamanho de determinados objetos, fazendo com que eles interagissem diretamente com o cenÃ¡rio para acessar novos locais, tornavam a experiÃªncia em algo surreal e engenhoso, desafiando o senso de percepÃ§Ã£o do jogador com problemas de raciocÃ­nio lÃ³gico suficientemente difÃ­ceis, mas ainda que permitiam que o prÃ³prio jogador chegasse em suas conclusÃµes sem precisar de dicas ou ajudas. Por sinal, tenho que enfatizar como essa mecÃ¢nica de proporÃ§Ãµes Ã© envolvente. Perdi as contas de quantas vezes eu parava de avanÃ§ar na histÃ³ria apenas para brincar com essas proporÃ§Ãµes, testando algumas das ideias que passavam na minha cabeÃ§a e vendo como elas se saiam quando eu as colocava em prÃ¡tica. Mesmo sem nenhum progresso, o simples ato de conhecer mais as um pouco das funcionalidades dessa mecÃ¢nica jÃ¡ era o suficiente para que eu me divertisse e continuasse engajado com sua proposta.

Outro fator que me motivou nesse engajamento contÃ­nuo foi essa sua narrativa sobre os processos do estabelecimento de um relacionamento amoroso. Mesmo que eu nÃ£o consiga fazer paralelos significativos dessa histÃ³ria com as mecÃ¢nicas do jogo, deixando ela um tanto quando desconexa com o resto da obra, eu simplesmente nÃ£o consegui deixar de ficar cativado pelos acontecimentos da mesma. Acompanhar de perto os eventos ilustrados de vÃ¡rios dos estÃ¡gios desse casal conseguiam me deixar curioso pelos rumos conturbados que ambos passavam, exalando sentimentos com bastante verossimilhanÃ§a. Parte desse mÃ©rito se dÃ¡ pela escolha dos dubladores, visto que sÃ£o atores reais e que entendem muito bem como transmitir essa emoÃ§Ã£o de maneira crÃ­vel e empÃ¡tica, mesmo que o recurso visual seja quase que inexistente. Essas pequenas doses de histÃ³ria espalhadas ao longo dos desafios serviam como recompensas para meu esforÃ§o, o que me motivava hÃ¡ continuar progredindo para chegar em sua resoluÃ§Ã£o, isso mesmo nos momentos em que o jogo comeÃ§ava a ficar maÃ§ante ou enjoativo.

Sim, esse momento inevitavelmente chegou. Mesmo que meu interesse por certos aspectos tenha me levado atÃ© a conclusÃ£o do jogo, nem mesmo suas mecÃ¢nicas ou sua histÃ³ria conseguiram sustentar a obra durante toda a experiÃªncia, e por volta da metade dessa aventura, eu jÃ¡ estava comeÃ§ando a me desanimar. Os puzzles comeÃ§aram a ficar cada vez menos interessantes, com um senso de proporÃ§Ã£o deturpado e que nÃ£o refletia aquela precisÃ£o das ideias apresentadas no comeÃ§o do jogo. Somado a isso, me locomover entre as maquetes tambÃ©m comeÃ§ou a se tornar num verdadeiro teste de paciÃªncia. Transitar entre essas maquetes era algo divertido no comeÃ§o, graÃ§as ao fascÃ­nio instantÃ¢neo que existia ao comparar as perspectivas das maquetes, mas nÃ£o demorou muito para que isso comeÃ§asse a ficar cansativo. Um dos motivos Ã© a ausÃªncia de uma opÃ§Ã£o de corrida, algo que faz muita falta quando Ã© preciso constantemente se locomover atÃ© a maquete com a perspectiva gigantesca. Realizar essa travessia por mais de uma vez quebrava muito o ritmo e me deixava irritado de certo modo, e mesmo que exista uma espÃ©cie de corrida automÃ¡tica em alguns momentos, ela nunca conseguia entregar o necessÃ¡rio para que eu sentisse o ritmo fluir nesses deslocamentos.

AlÃ©m disso, outro problema consideravelmente irritante foi em relaÃ§Ã£o a sua taxa de quadros. InÃºmeras pessoas reclamaram da sensaÃ§Ã£o estranha da fluidez da imagem, e eu me incluo nelas, pois Ã© simplesmente terrÃ­vel jogar com as quedas constantes. Mesmo com todas as mudanÃ§as grÃ¡ficas que fiz, eu tive uma enorme dor de cabeÃ§a durante todas Ã s vezes que joguei, o que me forÃ§ou a realizar pausas para relaxar meu cÃ©rebro e diminuir as dores que tive. E mesmo apÃ³s um ano e meio desde seu lanÃ§amento, os desenvolvedores nÃ£o se atentaram nesse defeito, o que se mostrou um desrespeito imenso com seus compradores. Adoraria chegar aqui e ressaltar como foi divertida e prazerosa toda a minha experiÃªncia, mas a realidade Ã© que apÃ³s o fascÃ­nio com a premissa passar, os problemas conceituais e de desempenho da obra me fizeram criar desgosto pela mesma. Passar pelos Ãºltimos momentos do jogo foi quase um desafio, o que Ã© uma pena, jÃ¡ que Ã© nessa parte que condensa os puzzles mais inventivos de toda a campanha. Posso atÃ© estar colocando muita Ãªnfase em como eu me senti lesado por esse aspecto tÃ©cnico, mas eu realmente nÃ£o esperava que algo tÃ£o simples pudesse me tirar completamente desse hype que eu estava pela obra.

Maquette parecia ser a nova joia bruta da Annapurna, trazendo mais uma experiÃªncia Ãºnica e cheia de inventividade para uma mÃ­dia saturada e que carece de novas ideias. Seus visuais conquistavam qualquer amante de obras independentes, alÃ©m de contar com uma trilha sonora poderosa e uma premissa curiosa, utilizando proporcionalidade como a base de seus puzzles. NÃ£o foi preciso muito tempo para eu perceber como suas mecÃ¢nicas eram divertidas e caprichadas, o que me motivava a ficar verificando as possibilidades que se abriam em minha mente para cada novo desafio que aparecia em meu caminho. Contudo, essa mecÃ¢nica nÃ£o foi o suficiente para me fazer ignorar os problemas de desempenho da versÃ£o de PC, com uma taxa de quadros extremamente instÃ¡vel e oscilante, tornando a experiÃªncia num verdadeiro sofrimento fÃ­sico e mental. E jÃ¡ nÃ£o bastasse isso, a prÃ³pria obra perde seu fascÃ­nio apÃ³s sua metade, o que ampliava cada vez mais a minha frustraÃ§Ã£o pelo potencial desperdiÃ§ado e pelos problemas tÃ©cnicos que permanecem incorrigÃ­veis atÃ© hoje. Diante do que parecia ser um novo clÃ¡ssico do gÃªnero de puzzles, Maquette se contenta como uma obra que alterna entre ser divertida e irritante, alÃ©m de ser particularmente uma decepÃ§Ã£o para mim, que coloquei tanta esperanÃ§a nesse tÃ­tulo.

Ã‰valuation publiÃ©e le 2 mars 2021
Jogo bonitinho que explora bem a recursividade!

Jogo bonitinho que explora bem a recursividade!

Ê²áµ’áµáµ’ áµ‡áµ’â¿á¶¦áµ—á¶¦â¿Ê°áµ’ áµ áµ˜áµ‰ áµ‰Ë£áµ–Ë¡áµ’Ê³áµƒ áµ‡áµ‰áµ áµƒ Ê³áµ‰á¶œáµ˜Ê³Ë¢á¶¦áµ›á¶¦áµˆáµƒáµˆáµ‰áµ
 
Gusteibou ğŸ§
506 produits enregistrÃ©s
0
13 personnes ont trouvÃ© cette Ã©valuation utile
0
Non recommandÃ©
3.9 h en tout
Ã‰valuation publiÃ©e le 12 mars 2021
Starting with the good stuff: The art direction is one of the BEST I've ever seen - the visuals are impressive and always bring something fresh from the beginning to the end of the experience, taking you by surprise with new colors, compositions and visual effects.

The core mechanic is great, puzzles have some good "a-ha" moments, and each level's design is pretty fun to explore for the first time. However, the pacing is a little bit odd - there are plenty of difficulty spikes caused by not having properly prepared the player for some challenges - I usually like puzzles that don't underestimate the player, but when there is an exploration element to the game it's easy to get stuck because you simply didn't notice something that should be easy to see - like understanding whether a platform is reachable by a jump or not, or not being 100% sure if you messed things up to the point you created a deadlock state. That is not a good puzzle, it's just bad ergonomics.

Also, although there are some interesting details in how the dialogue is written, narratively speaking Maquette unfortunately doesn't bring anything new to the table - other games have told the same story in very similar ways. There is a lot of influence from Florence but the use of "mechanics as metaphor" seem a little bit forced at some points, as the story feels a bit slapped on top of the "recursiveness" mechanic.

There were also plenty of game-breaking bugs on the release day, which made me re-start the levels from scratch (and watch all unskippable cutscenes again) several times. But I assume this will probably have already been fixed by the time I post this.

It hurts to give a "not recommended" because the visuals are amazing and the main mechanic is delightful to discover. A lot of work was clearly put into this game, but in terms of experience I think the full price is a little bit high, especially in a world with so many great indie puzzles being released all of the time - many of them published by Annapurna itself. If you are curious, I would recommend waiting for a bigger discount.
 
mimpedro
242 produits enregistrÃ©s
0
14 personnes ont trouvÃ© cette Ã©valuation utile
1 personne a trouvÃ© cette Ã©valuation amusante
1
Non recommandÃ©
8.5 h en tout
Ã‰valuation publiÃ©e le 23 juin 2021
I've been very on the fence about this game for a while, and to be honest I wish it weren't a game-crashing bug that pushed me off of it. (I was prepared to call this "a qualified yes", but...) Currently stuck in the final chapter, unable to finish, which is really unfortunate.

Here's the thing: there's a lot to like in this game. The puzzles are, generally speaking, very clever and interesting, and visually striking. The voice acting is great! The story is, well, OK, perhaps kind of a cliche (boy meets girl, boy and girl fall in love, boy and girl learn relationships take work and aren't communicating with each other, boy leaves girl, boy falls into depression, boy gets over it; this might have felt eye-opening and fresh when I was 20, but a quarter of a century later, not as much), but it's at least well-told.)

But then...

1. The gameplay is very linear. That makes sense, to an extent, because the story is very linear. (At least...kind of linear? Honestly, it's told in flashbacks and memories, so maybe it didn't have to be!) But it means that unlike other walk-around-and-solve-puzzles games, if you get stuck, you're stuck. There's no walking off, looking at something else for a while, coming back with fresh eyes. You're just stuck.

2. The graphics are great, but there's a downside: it's sometimes very hard to tell what's important and what's just scenery. We spent a lot of time walking over to every random bush, wall, corner, candle, what have you, trying to see if that's where we were supposed to do something.

3. Not unrelatedly: Maquette has that classic graphical-game problem where there's very little feedback. At one point we were close to doing the right thing, but couldn't tell we were close, we could only tell that what we were doing wasn't working. (For the record: we had put a ramp in the right place, but didn't realize we were supposed to put it sideways, so we could walk up the side of it.) At another point we were really, really far from doing the right thing, but once again had no idea whether it wasn't working because we hadn't quite done it right or because we were in totally the wrong place. (This one: We put the ramp outside the cathedral...and then went to the full-sized cathedral, walked up to the second floor, found bricks we could jump up on, tried jumping higher, spent a lot of time jumping, and eventually learned from a walkthrough that we were supposed to walk up the small ramp and just touch the bell on the model-sized cathedral.)

4. The idea of puzzles that involve changing perspectives is really cool--and I wish so much that the story was about changing perspectives, but most of the time the puzzle mechanics and the story are completely dissociated. (Not always: there are some places in The Spiral where, for instance, the text is about "not quite fitting" and the puzzle involves getting something to fit properly. But mostly.)

I see that this is the first game from these developers, and even with all that complaining, I'm genuinely looking forward to seeing what they do next; there's a lot in here that's good and I'm hoping that they can learn from the mistakes they made. Especially the game-crashing ones.
 
Tahnan
0
28 personnes ont trouvÃ© cette Ã©valuation utile
1 personne a trouvÃ© cette Ã©valuation amusante
1
RecommandÃ©
3.1 h en tout
Ã‰valuation publiÃ©e le 3 mars 2021
Hello Sunflower,

When Annapurna publishes a game you know it has something special, so far all the games they have published I fell in love with after playing them so no wonder why this publisher became one of my favorite of all time, itâ€™s a very simple rule, if itâ€™s an Annapurna published game, check it out, and here we are with Maquette, the newest published game from this amazing company, will Maquette deliver? Well, letâ€™s find out, shall we?

Michael and Kenzie, two strangers who meet by accident and from that precise moment something sparks, a love story full of emotions, a journey through the memories and experiences of this couple that will bring up moments of joy and moments of sadness in an oneiric world in which each situation has a form. A letter, a sketchbook and the voice of Michael are the means by which the story is told.

You can bet this is an Annapurna game because the story and narrative of this game is clearly their style, I must say something about it, the story is good and the plotline consistent, not only the voice work made it feel natural but also the relation between Michael and Kenzie felt like a day-to-day story and the way is being told is fantastic thanks to this floating sentences and the sketches from the book, however, I must say that I had a â€œDeja Vuâ€ moment by the end of the game and thatâ€™s because this game reminded me to another Annapurna game, that will be explained in the next spoiler section and I wonâ€™t give too much details.

Unfortunately I felt like the story was really similar to â€œFlorenceâ€ in the sense of the story developing in the same way, WHICH IS FINE because, letâ€™s be honest, relationships do work this way and most of the time end up like this but I kind of felt that Annapurna has 2 very similar games in their portfolio in terms of story, however, letâ€™s be honest, being compared to Florence is not a bad thing, on the contrary, this game has a very human story and unlike Florence, this one has much more potential in terms of gameplay, visuals and sound design.

If by any chance part of the dev team or part of the publishing team reads this, please, keep in mind this is not a bad thing, just had this feeling and I thought it was important to share it.

I have mentioned a lot the sketchbook element of this game and not without a good reason, the visual aspects of this game are quite interesting and charming, first we have varied arquitectonic styles within the structures, from the main maquette to the different buildings, all of them have a different style, in addition to this, from time to time we will experience a beautiful effect of air traces painting an scene that represents part of a conversation, part of where the action is taking place or a visual representation of the feelings, really beautiful effect that helps the general atmosphere.

We canâ€™t forget about the main attraction here, size changes based on what maquette are you in, wait what? Yes, there are different â€œlevelsâ€ of perspective to play, I will talk about the gameplay side of this later, right now I want to focus on the visual aspect of this mechanic, itâ€™s simply impressive at times, it might now be something new as we have seen this mechanic used in different games, however, Maquette does use it with a few tweaks here and there that creates a visual illusion that at times is breathtaking, like an infinite horizon or creating an infinite sky box of the main maquette building, I wonâ€™t spoil anything but there are a few times that it will amaze you.

When it comes to gameplay the game is very direct with the mechanics, on the one hand you walk, explore the environment and pick up things or activate mechanisms, on the other hand we have the perspective mechanic, what I was describing before itâ€™s the main mechanic of this game, we will have to go in or out of the maquettes in order to get new objects, reach places that werenâ€™t possible to access before.

This mechanic in particular isnâ€™t new at all but itâ€™s really well implemented and they nailed it when it comes to puzzle solving, sometimes you will be amazed how easy something was and you didnâ€™t see that coming, it is essential you keep your eye sharp because you will probably miss some details and mandatory elements to solve a puzzle or keep going with the story, that lever wonâ€™t be pulled alone and that gem wonâ€™t fit there, will it?

As a note, I only had a few minor glitches in the game and all happened when picking up objects, nothing game breaking, just a few glitches here and there but thatâ€™s it.

We talked about visuals and we talked about gameplay, whatâ€™s missing? Oh yeah, sound and music, another technical aspect nailed by the team, the OST is absolutely marvelous, such a great selection of tracks for each moment that brings up even a more powerful sense of the feeling they want to transmit with the letter but nothing does as much as the voice acting, they did an amazing job doing a very natural acting, joy, anger, sadness, each thing feels real, there is one dialog in particular mid-to-end of the game that woah, that anger was something else.

In conclusion, Maquette was an â€œAnnapurna seal of approvalâ€ game that was exactly what I was expecting, aside from the spoilered paragraph everything else felt really good, all the technical aspects were good, the story was good and in general I enjoyed my walkthrough.

Do I recommend this game? Yeah, right now we need stories that bring us a bit of joy and human feeling to the heart and this game does it, itâ€™s not too long, it is direct and it is a perfect game for a bit of passion and wholesome narrative, it might not be as lovely as you might find out, but hey, life is exactly that, experiences that we live and learn from.

That being said, I do encourage you to play the game and hopefully you will enjoy it like I did.

Goodbye, Sunflower.
 
Geekydeval

Personne ne peut prendre du plaisir, c'est un vÃ©ritable chemin de croix

Ce jeu, c'est comme si vous alliez voir un super film au cinÃ©ma et que le rÃ©alisateurs et les techniciens vous trollaient sans cesse en se levant, mangeant bruyamment, discutant ou en regardant leur tÃ©lÃ©phone. Ou comme si devant une bonne partie de jeu vidÃ©o, votre mÃ¨re venaient sans-cesse dÃ©brancher la prise de la console pour brancher l'aspirateur.

Je suis vraiment client de ce type de jeu Ã  Ã©nigmes, avec une histoire entre des personnages en toile de fond. J'ai adorÃ© Firewatch, What's Remain of Edith Finch, The Suicide of Rachel Foster, The Vanishing of Ethan Carter, The Whitness, Portal 1 et 2 etc... Et quand j'ai vu le trailer j'Ã©tais impatient de jouer Ã  ce Maquette que j'ai achetÃ© Day One.

Au dÃ©but, tout va bien, car les Ã©nigmes sont celles du trailer. Mais plus j'avance, plus il y a des bugs de collisions, des Ã©nigmes qui n'ont un sens que pour ceux ne l'ayant pas dÃ©veloppÃ©, ce qui fait que l'histoire en toile de fond, devient totalement anecdotique et frustrante parce que tuÃ© par le manque de finition technique et de gameplay.

Pour les Ã©nigmes, par exemple, on va nous prÃ©senter une Ã©nigme, puis Ã  la suivante, on se dit que Ã§a va Ãªtre Ã  peu prÃ¨s la mÃªme en plus difficile, et bien non ! La finalitÃ© est totalement alÃ©atoire au bon vouloir des crÃ©ateurs, ce qui donne vraiment le sentiment de truander le jeu et de rÃ©soudre l'Ã©nigme de maniÃ¨re non conventionnelle (sale) et ce n'est pas dutout satisfaisant. Et parfois truander est la solution, parfois pas et il faudra recharger la partie...
On se retrouve Ã  tenter de difficilement sauter partout, sur le moindre pixels, parfois Ã§a passe (l'Ã©preuve des bÃ¢timents tÃ©traminos vers la fin), parfois non (l'Ã©preuve de l'escalier)
Le jeu oublie totalement le joueur : "Tiens ! Prend cet objet et va le mettre en haut de cet arbre pour ouvrir la porte !" J'abuse Ã  peine : pour l'Ã©nigme se passant dans un quartier avec des petites maisons, j'Ã©tais coincÃ©, mais j'ai rÃ©ussi Ã  activer un interrupteur en sautant sur des tuyaux en abusant de la permissivitÃ© du moteur physique, s'en suivi un mouvement de camÃ©ra totalement bugguÃ©. Est ce que j'ai bien fait d'activer cet interrupteur ? Est ce que j'Ã©tais censÃ© pouvoir le faire ? J'en sais rien, c'est sale et frustrant.

On fait des allers-retours incessant entre la maquette gÃ©ante et celle Ã  bonne Ã©chelle (1/3 du temps de jeu), quand Ã  la petite maquette, aller dedans pour poser des Ã©lÃ©ments est un calvaire tant il y a des bugs de collisions avec les objets (escaliers, clÃ©s, cristaux...)

Les textes, racontant l'histoire, sont parfois une indications (grÃ¢ce Ã  leur position) vague pour rÃ©soudre une Ã©nigme, mais dans 90% des cas ne servent Ã  rien)

Ce jeu est une ode au bug : je me suis mis Ã  traverser les murs sans le vouloir (Ã©nigme des escalier), traverser le sol de l'aire de jeu pour me retrouver en dessous (Ã©nigme de l'escalier aussi). On peut se retrouver bloquÃ© bÃªtement Ã  cause d'une grossiÃ¨re erreur de Game Design (Ã©nigme des cristaux, ne passez SURTOUT PAS les cristaux par dessus le mur de l'enceinte !). Les objets que l'ont tient (comme les clÃ©s) traversent les murs ! Et Ã  la fin, lorsque l'ont peut retourner le dÃ´me, c'est bugguÃ© ! il se recentre de maniÃ¨re chelou parce qu'on ne peut pas le soulever, juste le tourner, c'est vraiment trÃ¨s mal fait !

Les dÃ©placements n'ont reÃ§u aucune finition, j'ai l'impression de me dÃ©placer dans un logiciel 3D et le saut est totalement bugguÃ©. La manipulation des objets, n'en parlons pas ! surtout dans la petite maquette c'est une horreur ! L'auto-lock dessus pÃªtera totalement l'affichage (notamment sur l'Ã©preuve des batiments tÃ©traminos),avec des objets qui tremble parce qu'Ã  moitiÃ© Ã  travers d'un Ã©lÃ©ment du dÃ©cor

Du coup : Recharger la partie, recharger la partie, recharger la partie... recharger la partie, je n'ai jamais autant rechargÃ© de fois la partie dans un jeu d'Ã©nigmes !

A la fin on ne souhaite qu'une seule chose : en finir avec ce terrible jeu !

Il est visiblement pas terminÃ© dutout ! C'est dommage il avait l'air prometteur.
 
Pierrot

13 personnes ont trouvÃ© cette Ã©valuation utile
0
RecommandÃ©
3.3 h en tout
Ã‰valuation publiÃ©e le 3 mars 2021
I had this game on my radar since I finished Outer Wilds and searched for what Annapurna published besides it.
The trailers had me intrigued, so I got it once it got onto steam.

I quite liked the game and would recommend it to fans of puzzles games, maybe to fans of narrative driven games as well.
Both recommondations come with some caviats though:

-Don't go in here looking for a long game. The game is short, I finished it in about 3h.
-Don't go in here looking for hard puzzles. The puzzles are rather tame. I looked up 2 solutions. One of them was because the game bugged out on me and the (valid) solution I already tried did not work (or let's say, the whole puzzle didn't actually work). The second one was because the solution was (imo) way out of the box (the game kinda threw me a curveball on this one, probably on purpose).
-Don't go in for a really deep story. The story is rather clichee imo, but it is well delivered and has an emotional effect.

Since the game is cheap, I am fine with it's shortness. I feel like the story wouldn't have been able to get stretched out further anyhow, so it's a plus that it did not drag on.

I am a bit sad that the game is so short because the general puzzle mechanic this game uses is quite unique and I would've like more and more complicated puzzles using it.


Oh and the KB+M controls can be really janky at times. It's not completely disfunctional, but some sections had my scratching my head.
Also there are no graphics options to speak of, besides a resolutions, 3 presets and a FOV-slider (I had to turn that down though, as the highest option, 90, brings heavy motion blur with it).
 
simbabwe

Jogabilidade muito boa, a expectativa que vocÃª tem vendo o trailer Ã© suprida e alÃ©m disso, superada, com uma Ã³tima narrativa, os desenvolvedores conseguiriam unir muito bem, arte, jogabilidade e histÃ³ria em uma coisa sÃ³. Eu nÃ£o esperava um jogo de puzzle que nos contasse uma histÃ³ria tÃ£o boa e emocionante, mesmo sendo simples consegue ser impactante, pois se trata de relacionamentos e sua efemeridade. O jogo dura entre 3h e 4h30, dependendo de quanto tempo vc vai ficar preso nos puzzles, recomendo fortemente que jogue ele de uma vez sÃ³, para aproveitar a narrativa e os altos e baixos da mesma.

0
Non recommandÃ©
5.7 h en tout
Ã‰valuation publiÃ©e le 22 aout 2022
Up until the final level I would have said that it's worth buying discounted if you are into puzzle games and if you aren't easily frustrated.

The game looks pretty nice and the core gameplay mechanics are kinda cool, which is great. What's not so great is that the controls are really weird. It is often harder to place the objects in the right spot than to figure out the right spot, which is frustrating. The story is also very superficial and told in a way that is not engaging at all. It's basically just text that pops up in the world and occasionally some dialog (audio only). It's supposed to be very emotional but fell completely flat for me. But other than that the puzzles are fun most of the time.

However the final level is so broken that I can't recommend this game to anyone. The game will randomly lock up completely when you interact with a specific item. This happened at least 6 times in a level that's supposed to take approximately 15 minutes.

Don't buy it. Not even if you are really into puzzle games and it is heavily discounted. This is not acceptable.
 
Popkornium18

Ğ’ Ñ†ĞµĞ½Ñ‚Ñ€Ğµ Ğ²Ğ½Ğ¸Ğ¼Ğ°Ğ½Ğ¸Ñ Ğ±ÑƒĞ´ĞµÑ‚ Ğ¸ÑÑ‚Ğ¾Ñ€Ğ¸Ñ Ğ»ÑĞ±Ğ²Ğ¸ ĞšĞµĞ½Ğ·Ğ¸ Ğ¸ ĞœĞ°Ğ¹ĞºĞ»Ğ°. Ğ’Ğ½ĞµĞ·Ğ°Ğ¿Ğ½Ğ°Ñ, ÑÑ€ĞºĞ°Ñ Ğ¸ Ğ¾Ğ¿ÑƒÑÑ‚Ğ¾ÑˆĞ°ÑÑ‰Ğ°Ñ. ĞœÑ‹ Ğ±ÑƒĞ´ĞµĞ¼ Ğ² Ñ€Ğ¾Ğ»Ğ¸ ÑĞ»ÑƒÑˆĞ°Ñ‚ĞµĞ»Ñ, ĞºĞ¾Ñ‚Ğ¾Ñ€Ñ‹Ğ¹ Ğ²Ğ¸Ğ´Ğ¸Ñ‚ Ğ²Ğ·Ğ»ĞµÑ‚Ñ‹ Ğ¸ Ğ¿Ğ°Ğ´ĞµĞ½Ğ¸Ñ ÑÑ‚Ğ¾Ğ¹ Ğ¿Ğ°Ñ€Ğ¾Ñ‡ĞºĞ¸. ĞĞ¸Ñ‡ĞµĞ³Ğ¾ ÑĞ²ĞµÑ€Ñ…ÑŠĞµÑÑ‚ĞµÑÑ‚Ğ²ĞµĞ½Ğ½Ğ¾Ğ³Ğ¾ Ğ¼Ñ‹ Ñ‚ÑƒÑ‚ Ğ½Ğµ ÑƒĞ²Ğ¸Ğ´Ğ¸Ğ¼, Ğ´Ğ° Ğ¸ Ñ„Ğ¸Ğ½Ğ°Ğ» Ğ²Ñ‹ÑˆĞµĞ» Ğ¿Ñ€ĞµĞ´ÑĞºĞ°Ğ·ÑƒĞµĞ¼Ñ‹Ğ¼. ĞŸĞ¾ÑĞ»Ğµ What Remains of Edith Finch Ğ²ÑĞµ Ğ¼Ğ¾Ğµ ÑÑƒÑ‰ĞµÑÑ‚Ğ²Ğ¾ Ğ¶ĞµĞ»Ğ°Ğ»Ğ¾ Ğ¸Ğ½Ñ‚ĞµÑ€ĞµÑĞ½Ğ¾Ğ¹ Ğ¸ Ğ´ÑƒÑˆĞµÑ‰Ğ¸Ğ¿Ğ°Ñ‚ĞµĞ»ÑŒĞ½Ğ¾Ğ¹ Ğ¸ÑÑ‚Ğ¾Ñ€Ğ¸Ğ¸, Ğ¿Ñ€Ğ¾ Ğ¶Ğ¸Ğ·Ğ½ĞµĞ½Ğ½Ñ‹Ğµ Ğ¾Ğ±ÑÑ‚Ğ¾ÑÑ‚ĞµĞ»ÑŒÑÑ‚Ğ²Ğ°, Ğ½Ğ¾ Ñ Ğ±Ñ‹Ğ» Ñ€Ğ°Ğ·Ğ¾Ñ‡Ğ°Ñ€Ğ¾Ğ²Ğ°Ğ½. Ğ˜Ğ½Ğ¾Ğ³Ğ´Ğ° Ğ½Ğµ ÑÑ‚Ğ¾Ğ¸Ñ‚ Ñ€Ğ¸ÑĞ¾Ğ²Ğ°Ñ‚ÑŒ Ğ² Ğ³Ğ¾Ğ»Ğ¾Ğ²Ğµ Ğ²Ğ¾Ğ·Ğ´ÑƒÑˆĞ½Ñ‹Ğµ Ğ·Ğ°Ğ¼ĞºĞ¸, Ñ‡Ñ‚Ğ¾Ğ±Ñ‹ Ğ½Ğµ ÑÑ‚Ğ°Ñ‚ÑŒ Ğ¿Ğ»ĞµĞ½Ğ½Ğ¸ĞºĞ¾Ğ¼ ÑĞ²Ğ¾Ğ¸Ñ… Ğ¾Ğ¶Ğ¸Ğ´Ğ°Ğ½Ğ¸Ğ¹.

Ğ“ĞµĞ¹Ğ¼Ğ¿Ğ»ĞµĞ¹ Ñ‚Ğ°ĞºĞ¾Ğ¹ Ğ¶Ğµ ÑÑƒÑ…Ğ¾Ğ¹ Ğ¸ Ñ‡ĞµÑ€ÑÑ‚Ğ²Ñ‹Ğ¹. ĞĞµÑĞ¼Ğ¾Ñ‚Ñ€Ñ Ğ½Ğ° ÑÑ€ĞºÑƒÑ Ñ†Ğ²ĞµÑ‚Ğ°ÑÑ‚ÑƒÑ ĞºĞ°Ñ€Ñ‚Ğ¸Ğ½ĞºÑƒ Ğ¸ Ğ¿Ñ€Ğ¸ÑÑ‚Ğ½Ğ¾Ğµ Ğ¼ÑƒĞ·Ñ‹ĞºĞ°Ğ»ÑŒĞ½Ğ¾Ğµ ÑĞ¾Ğ¿Ñ€Ğ¾Ğ²Ğ¾Ğ¶Ğ´ĞµĞ½Ğ¸Ğµ, ÑÑ‚Ğ° Ğ¸Ğ³Ñ€Ğ° Ğ½Ğµ Ğ±Ğ»ĞµÑ‰ĞµÑ‚ Ñ€Ğ°Ğ·Ğ½Ğ¾Ğ¾Ğ±Ñ€Ğ°Ğ·Ğ¸ĞµĞ¼. Ğ¢ÑƒÑ‚ Ğ½Ğ°Ğ´Ğ¾ Ğ½Ğ°Ğ¹Ñ‚Ğ¸ Ğ¸ Ğ²ÑÑ‚Ğ°Ğ²Ğ¸Ñ‚ÑŒ Ğ½ÑƒĞ¶Ğ½Ñ‹Ğ¹ Ğ¿Ñ€ĞµĞ´Ğ¼ĞµÑ‚, Ñ‚ÑƒÑ‚ Ğ´Ğ¾Ğ´ÑƒĞ¼Ğ°Ñ‚ÑŒÑÑ Ğ²Ñ‹Ñ‚Ğ°Ñ‰Ğ¸Ñ‚ÑŒ ĞºĞ»ÑÑ‡ Ğ¸Ğ· Ğ·Ğ°Ğ±Ğ»Ğ¾ĞºĞ¸Ñ€Ğ¾Ğ²Ğ°Ğ½Ğ½Ğ¾Ğ¹ Ğ»Ğ¾ĞºĞ°Ñ†Ğ¸Ğ¸, Ğ° Ñ‚ÑƒÑ‚ Ğ¿Ğ¾Ğ´Ğ¾Ğ±Ñ€Ğ°Ñ‚ÑŒ Ğ½ÑƒĞ¶Ğ½ÑƒÑ Ğ¿ĞµÑ€ÑĞ¿ĞµĞºÑ‚Ğ¸Ğ²Ñƒ Ğ´Ğ»Ñ Ğ¿Ñ€ĞµĞ´Ğ¼ĞµÑ‚Ğ°. Ğ“ĞµĞ¹Ğ¼Ğ¿Ğ»ĞµĞ¹ Ğ¾Ñ‡ĞµĞ½ÑŒ Ğ½Ğ°Ğ¿Ğ¾Ğ¼Ğ¸Ğ½Ğ°ĞµÑ‚ Superliminal, Ñ‚Ğ¾Ğ»ÑŒĞºĞ¾ Ğ² Ğ±Ğ¾Ğ»ĞµĞµ ÑĞºÑ€Ğ¾Ğ¼Ğ½Ğ¾Ğ¼ Ğ²Ğ¸Ğ´Ğµ. Ğ”Ğ»Ğ¸Ñ‚ÑÑ ÑÑ‚Ğ¾ "Ğ²Ğ¾Ğ»ÑˆĞµĞ±ÑÑ‚Ğ²Ğ¾" Ğ¾ĞºĞ¾Ğ»Ğ¾ 5 Ñ‡Ğ°ÑĞ¾Ğ² Ğ¸ Ğ·Ğ° ÑÑ‚Ğ¾ Ğ²Ñ€ĞµĞ¼Ñ Ñ Ğ½Ğµ Ğ½Ğ°ÑˆĞµĞ» Ğ´Ğ»Ñ ÑĞµĞ±Ñ Ğ½Ğ¸Ñ‡ĞµĞ³Ğ¾ Ğ¸Ğ½Ñ‚ĞµÑ€ĞµÑĞ½Ğ¾Ğ³Ğ¾.

Ğ•ÑĞ»Ğ¸ Ñ€Ğ°ÑÑĞ¼Ğ°Ñ‚Ñ€Ğ¸Ğ²Ğ°Ñ‚ÑŒ Maquette ĞºĞ°Ğº Ğ¿Ñ€Ğ¸ĞºĞ»ÑÑ‡ĞµĞ½Ğ¸Ğµ Ğ½Ğ° Ğ¾Ğ´Ğ¸Ğ½ Ğ²ĞµÑ‡ĞµÑ€, Ñ‚Ğ¾ Ğ²ÑĞµ Ğ¾Ñ‡ĞµĞ½ÑŒ Ğ´Ğ°Ğ¶Ğµ Ğ½ĞµĞ¿Ğ»Ğ¾Ñ…Ğ¾. ĞšÑ€Ğ°ÑĞ¸Ğ²Ğ°Ñ ĞºĞ°Ñ€Ñ‚Ğ¸Ğ½ĞºĞ° Ğ² ÑĞ¾Ñ‡ĞµÑ‚Ğ°Ğ½Ğ¸Ğ¸ Ñ Ğ¿Ñ€Ğ¸ÑÑ‚Ğ½Ñ‹Ğ¼ Ğ¼ÑƒĞ·Ñ‹ĞºĞ°Ğ»ÑŒĞ½Ñ‹Ğ¼ ÑĞ¾Ğ¿Ñ€Ğ¾Ğ²Ğ¾Ğ¶Ğ´ĞµĞ½Ğ¸ĞµĞ¼ Ğ¸ Ğ½ĞµĞ½Ğ°Ğ²ÑÑ‰Ğ¸Ğ²Ñ‹Ğµ Ğ³Ğ¾Ğ»Ğ¾Ğ²Ğ¾Ğ»Ğ¾Ğ¼ĞºĞ¸. ĞĞ¾ Ñ Ğ²Ğ¸Ğ´ĞµĞ» Ğ´Ğ¾ÑÑ‚Ğ°Ñ‚Ğ¾Ñ‡Ğ½Ğ¾ Ğ¸Ğ³Ñ€ Ğ¾Ñ‚ Ğ¸Ğ·Ğ´Ğ°Ñ‚ĞµĞ»Ñ ANNAPURNA Ğ¸ Ğ·Ğ½Ğ°Ñ Ñ‡Ñ‚Ğ¾ Ğ¾Ğ½Ğ¸ Ğ¼Ğ¾Ğ³ÑƒÑ‚ Ğ²Ñ‹Ğ´Ğ°Ğ²Ğ°Ñ‚ÑŒ Ğ³Ğ¾Ñ€Ğ°Ğ·Ğ´Ğ¾ Ğ±Ğ¾Ğ»ĞµĞµ ĞºĞ°Ñ‡ĞµÑÑ‚Ğ²ĞµĞ½Ğ½Ñ‹Ğµ Ğ¿Ñ€Ğ¾ĞµĞºÑ‚Ñ‹. Ğ¯ ĞºĞ¾Ğ½ĞµÑ‡Ğ½Ğ¾ Ğ±Ñ‹Ğ» Ğ½ĞµĞ¼Ğ½Ğ¾Ğ³Ğ¾ Ñ€Ğ°ÑÑÑ‚Ñ€Ğ¾ĞµĞ½ ÑƒĞ²Ğ¸Ğ´ĞµĞ½Ğ½Ñ‹Ğ¼, Ğ½Ğ¾ Ñ‚Ğ¾ Ñ‡Ñ‚Ğ¾ Ñ…Ğ¾Ñ‚ĞµĞ» Ğ¿Ğ¾Ğ»ÑƒÑ‡Ğ¸Ğ» - Ğ³Ğ¾Ğ»Ğ¾Ğ²Ğ¾Ğ»Ğ¾Ğ¼ĞºĞ¸ Ğ¸ Ğ¿Ñ€Ğ¸ÑÑ‚Ğ½Ñ‹Ğ¹ ÑÑ€ĞºĞ¸Ğ¹ Ğ²Ğ¸Ğ·ÑƒĞ°Ğ».
 
Ne_0N DEM#N
1,785 produits enregistrÃ©s
2
10 personnes ont trouvÃ© cette Ã©valuation utile
0
RecommandÃ©
4.9 h en tout
Ã‰valuation publiÃ©e le 10 avril 2021
Maquette is a perfect example of why Steam review ratings need to be more granular than "yes" or "no".

The story tackles a common life event that isn't all that commonly the focus of game stories, so is quite interesting in that respect. It is also told entirely through narration via some pretty good voice acting. I personally felt the female voice was considerably more convincing than the male voice, though can't really put my finger on why, but ultimately I felt the story was very well told.

The gameplay has you exploring this artistically beautiful recursive world which hold elements of the memories of the two narrators. You move through these memories by solving puzzles which typically involve negotiating dimension bending big and bigger, and little and littler versions of the environment you're in. Conceptually pretty cool.

Unfortunately, a lot of the puzzle solving is pretty janky and feels kind of half-baked in places. Some puzzles get you really thinking, which is a good thing, but other times you're left wondering if you actually did some puzzles right or if you just abused the game's mechanics and got away with it.

Most puzzles are solved by picking up an object, carrying and moving it around, but the pick, carrying and moving mechanics just feel broken. Honestly, the unclear puzzles wouldn't even be half as frustrating if it just "felt" good to hold and move stuff.

There's only a few "cut scenes" for when a puzzle is solved, the rest of the time you are left awkwardly platforming a slow moving, low jumping character over a bridge or ramp you have placed, struggling to reach the end and unsure if you've just missed something somewhere or if the actual intended solution is just this rough.

Ultimately though, I enjoyed my time with the game. The way it told its story is unique and engaging, the world is beautiful and pleasant to be in, and the puzzle concept is interesting and fairly unique despite its roughness.
 
Casperr

Ã‰valuation publiÃ©e le 10 dÃ©cembre 2022
I wanted to like this game, I really did. In theory it has a lot going for it from the interesting story to the absolutely beautiful visualss... but it just does everything possible to make liking it impossible.

It's glitchy, there is no v-sync, you will be soft locked often, it crashes, the puzzles are unwieldy and most of them are pretty unengaging, the few puzzles that are actually difficult are only difficult because their parameters are poorly explained to the player or just not explained it all. The list of â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ is a mile long.

I'm sorry to the devs, but I DNF. I don't recommend. Skip.

Non recommandÃ©
2.6 h en tout
Ã‰valuation publiÃ©e le 24 juillet 2021
I was really disappointed with this game having expected an experience in a similar vein to Superliminal. The puzzles do not feel mentally challenging at all. Instead it's more a case of walking around and trying to interact with everything, anything, only to find that one object is the only thing used through the majority of the level. There were also cheap tricks such as mechanics which only work once and then the rules seem to change without warning. In addition, you end up doing most of this in silence since once the song to enter the new section ends, no background sound/music is added thereafter. Lastly I found what I heard of the story cliche and the voice actors performances were not good enough to carry a sup par script with the female actresses interpretation being particularly irritating.
 
SummerFury
0
20 personnes ont trouvÃ© cette Ã©valuation utile
0
Non recommandÃ©
5.7 h en tout
Ã‰valuation publiÃ©e le 21 avril 2023
The puzzles are somewhat simplistic and the level design could do more to guide the player to solutions, especially early on, because even though the puzzles are simple, you may miss the solution because you just have no idea what you're looking for.

The story is also simplistic, one-dimensional, and frankly, a bit played out. The pacing felt wrong, the relationship's turn for the worse seemed to happen quite suddenly, even though it was clear from the very beginning that's where the story was heading. In the end, I didn't really care about the characters, they're totally uninteresting. And the angry shouting match was completely unnecessary, and frankly, hard to listen to. Maybe the developers should try some nuance or subtlety in their next game.

Movement was a bit janky, and so was the camera. I'm not sure what else I can say here.

At around 6 hours, I'd complain about the game being too short, except by the time I reached the ending, I was happy to move onto something else.

TL;DR: go play Florence instead. It's got a relationship, it's got ups and downs, it's got puzzles, and is a delight to play.
 
Cowboy

12 personnes ont trouvÃ© cette Ã©valuation utile

Non recommandÃ©
6.5 h en tout
Ã‰valuation publiÃ©e le 6 mars 2021
I was sold on this from it's core mechanic of the recursive paradox world, but this has very few applications. With one or two exceptions the puzzles were quite simplistic. A lot of the interaction felt like padding to space out a fairly bland plot about a guy getting the feels over his relationship failing.
Visually it's fantastic, but the excellent level design is eschewed for doodle like animatic scenes for all the plot, which serves to pull focus from the mechanical concept. The plot and the theme might have worked well in a different game, but they had absolutely nothing to do with your actions in this game, and seemed to serve as nothing more than a distraction to space out barely an hours worth of puzzles in a world that is beautifully detailed, but interactively rather sparse.

It's alright, you'd expect explorations of fractal space from the trailer, and there's a tiny bit of that at the end of the game, but most of the game is a walking sim. The story sucks, there's very few puzzles and most of them are trivial, akin to a hidden object game where you have to click on the right thing.

The idea is interesting and the last three puzzles in the game are cool, so a weak thumbs up I guess.

11 personnes ont trouvÃ© cette Ã©valuation utile
1
Non recommandÃ©
3.2 h en tout
Ã‰valuation publiÃ©e le 1 janvier 2022
A short puzzle game with puzzles based around interacting with the same objects at different scales. Padded with a sequence of tedious but skippable spoken dialogs about a failed relationship.

A few of the puzzles are unintuitive and/or involve a lot of walking long distances, and the last level crashes if you interact with the main object the wrong way (the object is recursive, and you have to be careful to select the outermost object; the game crashes it you accidentally select the inner one).

It has a lot of promise, but the execution is underwhelming and timid. Toward the end I found myself just pushing through it as fast as I could and relying on FAQs for the more unintuitive puzzle solutions because I wasn't enjoying it anymore and just wanted to be done with it.

This sums up the game itself as well.
